abs: In many schemes for digital watermarking, an attacker in possession of a small fixed number of di#erently marked copies of a single document can easily produce an unmarked copy. In contrast, we show in this paper that if the watermarks have a component-wise normal distribution, then # p n/ ln m di#erently marked copies are required to successfully erase any mark with non-negligible probability. Here n is the dimensionality of the watermarks, and m is the number of di#erently marked copies distributed. This result holds in a specific but natural statistical model of watermarking. 1 NEC Research Institute, 4 Independence Way, Princeton, NJ 08540. 2 Dept. of Mathematics, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139. 3 STAR Lab, InterTrust Technologies, 460 Oakmead Parkway, Sunnyvale, CA 94026. 4 Department of Computer Science, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544. Research at Princeton University partially supported by the National Science Foundation, Grant...
title: Resistance of Digital Watermarks to Collusive Attacks
